description:
Pieris napi, commonly known as the green-veined white or small white, is a species of butterfly belonging to the family Pieridae. It is a small to medium-sized butterfly with a wingspan ranging from 45 to 60 millimeters.

The upper side of the wings is white, with black tips on the forewings. The underside of the wings is a pale greenish-white color, with distinct green veins, which give the butterfly its common name. The body is generally black or dark grey in color.

Pieris napi is widely distributed across Europe, Asia, and North Africa, and can be found in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, meadows, and forest edges. The larvae, or caterpillars, feed on various species of cruciferous plants, such as cabbage and mustard.

The life cycle of Pieris napi includes four distinct stages: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult (butterfly). The species can undergo multiple generations per year, with the number of generations varying depending on the geographical location and climatic conditions.

Pieris napi is an important pollinator and plays a role in the ecosystem, contributing to the overall diversity and balance of the natural environment.
